DISCHARGE LABS: 07:39AM BLOOD WBC-7.6 RBC-3.14* Hgb-9.5* Hct-28.4* MCV-90 MCH-30.4 MCHC-33.6 RDW-13.9 Plt 07:39AM BLOOD Glucose-119* UreaN-32* Creat-1.5* Na-138 K-4.9 Cl-105 HCO3-25 AnGap-13 Brief Hospital Course: , an yo F PMHx CKD III baseline Cr 1.6, HTN, T2DM presents with groin rash/pruritis complicated by acute on chronic kidney disease with hyperkalemia/metabolic acidosis and atrial fibrillation with slowed ventricular rate. Her hyperkalemia, AoCKD, and acidosis resolved with IV hydration, bicarbonate infusions, dextrose/insulin, and laxatives including kayexolate (were stable >24 hours without intervention prior to discharge). Her groin cellulitis (likely in setting of candidal intertrigo) was initially treated with vancomycin/ceftriaxone and narrowed to amoxicillin-clavulanate/doxycline along with miconazole powder with continued improvement in signs/symptoms and lack of fever. She was noted to have atrial fibrillation with ventricular rates (no clear lightheadedness, presyncope, chest pain, or dyspnea); per patient she had this for years but per PCP notes and EKGs patient had no history of this from onward. Patient was started on apixaban in discussion with patient, inpatient team, cardiology, and primary team. recommended rehab given deconditioning and health situation of her brother. # Atrial Fibrillation with Slow Ventricular Response / Asymptomatic Bradycardia: Per patient report she has had atrial fibrillation for years (CHADS 3 for HTN, Age, DM but not on anticoagulation or rate/rhythm control) but currently noted to be in persistent/permanent atrial fibrillation with slowed ventricular response (likely worsened in the setting of hyperkalemia and acidemia). However her electrical rhythm did not normalize with normalization of electrolytes. ICU consulted Electrophysiology Consult who felt that she she be anticoagulated and should followup with an outpatient cardiologist. She was put on apixaban 2.5mg PO BID (due to age and renal function), was monitored on telemetry (AFib with HR generally 40-60s occasionally or , and an echocardiogram showed only mild structural heart disease. # Hyperkalemia / Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis / Acute on Chronic Kidney Disease: Patient with CKD Stage III presents with Cr 2.7 from 1.5-1.6 baseline in setting of poor PO intake as well as hyperkalemia and nonunion gap metabolic acidosis. Nephrology was consulted for assistance. is likely a prerenal process given improvement with IVF (renal ultrasound unremarkable aside from mild cortical thickening with normal LDH nonsuggestive of infearction, urine electrolytes suggest a sodium-conserving process). Hyperkalemia is most likely multifactorial with and acidemia contributing possibly with concomitant renal tubular acidosis. have component of chronic respiratory acidosis from obesity hypoventilation. Bradycardia most likely secondary to acidemia and elevated K but no evidence of other ECG changes. Patient would most likely have Type IV RTA given diabetes mellitus and hyperkalemia this this is a challenging diagnosis to make in the setting of . From , she was given several doses of insulin/D50, kayexolate, calcium carbonate, and 5 liters of intravenous bicarbonate with resolution of her hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis. On , her electrolytes and renal function normalized and were maintained from without interventions. Lisinopril was held due to advanced age, near-normotension, and concern for future hyperkalemia. # Groin Rash / Candidal Intertrigo with Secondary Bacterial Cellulitis: Patient noted to have right groin erythema/pruritis for 2 weeks prior to admission (possibly secondary to lack of ability to do laudry at home). Topical antifungals improved the pruritis but not the rash and patient began to have systemic symptoms (poor PO intake, malaise, . Differential includes cellulitis (but improvement with topical antifungals, maybe be superimposed on intertriginous process) versus intertrigo (no satellite lesions, fluid filled vesicles). Antibiotic regimen was initialy vancomycin/ceftriaxone, stepped down to ceftriaxone, and finally to amoxicillin-clavulanate/doxycycline for total course of 7 days. She was continued on Amox-Clav and Doxycyline through and Miconazole Powder through . # Acute Gout Flare: Patient complained of pain in left and right MTP joints and was noted at 11:15 on to have a red swollen and clearly tender right MTP joint. Due to precarious renal function (contraindications to NSAIDs and colcichine), patient was started on prednisone 40mg PO daily x3 days (given resolution of symptoms within 24 hours of treatment) 30mg x3 days, 20mg x3 days, 10mg x3 days then discontinuation. # Type II Diabetes Mellitus on oral medications: Chronic stable issue on ISS and diabetic diet with home glipizide being held as inpatient; due to overall stability of her diabetes her fingersticks were reduced to AM fasting with sliding scale starting at >200 but this was reconsidered due to use of corticosteroids for gout. # Hypertension: Chronic stable issue continued on home amlodipine but lisinopril held given . Her systolic blood pressures in house were maintained between 110-150s. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). Discharge Instructions: Dear Ms. , It was a pleasure to take care of you at . You were admitted to the hospital because you had an infection of your groin, a very slow heart rate, and poor kidney function with resulting electrolyte problems. We gave you IV fluids and medications to reduce your potassium and your kidney function went back to its previous function. We gave you antibiotics which are successfully treating your cellulitis. We also monitored your heart rate (stable but irregular, not causing symptoms) and put you on medications to make sure that this heart rhythm won't cause strokes. We also had Physical Therapy evaluate you to make sure you would be safe at home; they felt you would be best served with rehab. We also gave you a short course of steroids for your gout. Best of luck to you in your future health. Please take all medications as prescribed, attend all doctors as , and call a doctor if you have any questions or concerns.
